properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice is being issued for Portland.

  • A shark has been sighted in the Portland area today. 
  • Identified as a great white shark, approximately 3 metres in length, the most recent sighting was around 200 m from the Portland Lighthouse.
  • Due to two whale carcasses in the area, it is likely that shark activity closer to the shore may continue in the days to come. 
  • This Advice replaces the Advice message issued 30 January at 5.11 pm. 
Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.
What you should do: 
  • If you see the shark, report the sighting by calling Triple Zero (000) or notify lifesavers immediately if you are at a patrolled beach.
  • Always swim, dive or surf with a friend. 
  • Swim between the red and yellow flags on patrolled beaches.
  • Don't swim in places where human or animal waste enters the water. 
  • Keep away from large schools of fish, seals or other wildlife as these can attract sharks. 
Impacts in your area:
  • The following beach is closed: Nuns Beach between Lee Breakwater and Portland Lighthouse.
This message was issued by Victorian Fisheries Authority.

The next update is expected by 01/02/2023 04:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
ADVICE - DANGEROUS ANIMAL - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Portland
Issue Date: Tuesday 31 January 2023, 08:43 am
Next Update: Wednesday 01 February 2023, 04:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/28696/moreinfo

This Advice is being issued for Portland.

- A shark has been sighted in the Portland area today. 
- Identified as a great white shark, approximately 3 metres in length, the most recent sighting was around 200 m from the Portland Lighthouse.
- Due to two whale carcasses in the area, it is likely that shark activity closer to the shore may continue in the days to come. 
- This Advice replaces the Advice message issued 30 January at 5.11 pm. 


Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Portland, Portland North.

  •  Due to two whale carcasses there could be an increase in shark activity reported at Portland.
  • A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
  • While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued on Monday 23 January at 11.50am. 
Avoid the area. Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.
What you should do:

  • If you see sharks, report the sighting by calling Triple Zero (000) or notify lifesavers immediately if you are at a patrolled beach.
Staying safe at nearby beaches:
  • Always swim, dive or surf with a friend.
  • Swim between the red and yellow flags on patrolled beaches.
  • Don't swim in places where human or animal waste enters the water.
  • Keep away from large schools of fish, seals or other wildlife as these can attract sharks.
Impacts in your area:
  • The Victorian Fisheries Authority is monitoring for shark sightings and providing advice to relevant authorities. 
This message was issued by Victorian Fisheries.

The next update is expected by 06/02/2023 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.   
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Parts of Mildura, Nichols Point and Bruces Bend
properties.webBody:
The Emergency Warning to Evacuate, following flooding in parts of Mildura, Nichols Point and Bruces Bend has been lifted and it is Safe to Return.

  • Dangerous hazards including floodwater, mud, debris, damaged roads and fallen trees may still be present.
  • Many roads in the area have been impacted by floodwater. Keep up-to-date with local road closures at www.mildura.vic.gov.au/flood
It is now safe to return the evacuated area to assess impacts as the threat is reduced. Be aware of any hazards that may still exist in the warning area.
What you should do:
  • Visit the Mildura Rural City Council Flood Support and Recovery website for the latest information, road closures and support available. Go to www.mildura.vic.gov.au/Community/Flood-Support-and-Recovery
Mosquitos:
  • Mosquitos can carry diseases which are spread through mosquito bites.
  • Murray Valley encephalitis virus and West Nile/Kunjin virus have been detected in mosquitoes in the Mildura area.
  • Residents and people visiting Mildura are strongly advised to reduce their risk of mosquito bites.
More information:
  • www.health.vic.gov.au/health-alerts/murray-valley-encephalitis-virus-detected-in-victoria
  • www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/protect-yourself-mosquito-borne-disease
Kerbside flood waste collection:
  • Eligible residents can have flood waste collected for free through the Emergency Recovery Victoria (ERV) Street Debris Removal program between Monday 30 January and Friday 3 February.
  • To register, call Mildura Rural City Council on 5018 8100.The service will operate from Monday 30 January to Friday 3 February 2023. Once you have been confirmed as eligible for the program, waste and debris can be left on kerbsides or nature strips and will be picked up by licenced contractors.
Flood waste disposal:
  • If your property or business was affected by flood water or had items such as trees and other debris left behind, you can dispose of this waste free-of-charge at the Mildura Landfill.
  • Mildura Landfill is the only facility licensed to accept asbestos waste. If you need to dispose of asbestos, bookings need to be made. For more information visit www.mildura.vic.gov.au/Services/Waste-Management/Asbestos-Soil-Disposal
Sandbags:
  • Sandbags that come into contact with flood water are deemed to be contaminated and must be disposed of at the Mildura Landfill. There will be no charge for this.
  • Always wear gloves when handling used sandbags and other flood-related waste.
  • Make sure to separate clean and contaminated sandbags.
  • Sandbags that have NOT come into contact with flood water can either be emptied onto gardens, retained for future use, or taken to the Mildura Landfill, however there will be a charge if taken to landfill as this is not classified as flood waste.
Before taking your flood waste or contaminated sandbags to Mildura Landfill, call 5018 8100 and provide your details so that staff are ready to assist you when you arrive.

Structural assessments:
  • Property owners can register for a free all-hazard structural assessment if their property was damaged by the 2022 flood event.
  • This assessment can be used to identify any hazards, such as asbestos, giving guidance as to how the structure needs to be managed.
  • To register call ERV's Flood Response Hotline 1800 560 760 or register online here. Once you have registered, ERV will contact you and process your registration and then book an assessment time.
Impacts in your area:
  • Nichols Point Cemetery re-opened on Friday 27 January. Access is via Benetook Avenue (also known as Benetook Avenue extension). Karadoc Avenue is still closed to traffic as we assess soil conditions beneath the road. The Mildura Cemeteries Trust would like to thank the community for their patience during the closure.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

This will be the last warning issued for this flood.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text: ADVICE - RIVERINE FLOOD - Threat is Reduced Incident Location: Parts of Mildura, Nichols Point and Bruces Bend Issue Date: Monday 30 January 2023, 05:41 pm Next Update: Tuesday 31 January 2023, 05:50 pm More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/28690/moreinfo The Emergency Warning to Evacuate, following flooding in parts of Mildura, Nichols Point and Bruces Bend has been lifted and it is Safe to Return. - Dangerous hazards including floodwater, mud, debris, damaged roads and fallen trees may still be present. - Many roads in the area have been impacted by floodwater. Keep up-to-date with local road closures at www.mildura.vic.gov.au/flood It is now safe to return the evacuated area to assess impacts as the threat is reduced. Be aware of any hazards that may still exist in the warning area.
